awd_titl_txt: S&AS: FND: COLLAB: Planning and Control of Heterogeneous Robot Teams for Ocean Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots in marine and littoral environments are envisioned for commerce, scientific exploration, search and rescue, and many other tasks. However, robots in such environments face significant challenges. Vehicles must act and effect change in environments with large inertial effects and disturbances, with only near-field perception. Coupled with our limited understanding of ocean dynamics and the lack of accessible and high-quality ocean flow data, these obstacles make the use of robotics technology in these varied applications extremely difficult. This project realizes an integrated, heterogeneous robotic approach towards large-scale ocean monitoring for environmental mitigation and search and rescue operations. It enables data-driven tracking and mapping of various physical, chemical, and/or biological processes of interest in marine environments, such as tracking contaminant dispersion or missing aircraft. This project significantly improves the state of the art in ocean search and monitoring technology, helping us understand and harness ocean currents, and improve the health of the world's oceans. Results from the project are integrated into education, through the PIs' courses, mentoring students on research, and expanding an existing K-12 outreach relationship. 
 
The project creates fundamental knowledge about new ways that robots can better monitor, sense, and operate in dynamic and uncertain environments. The project develops new methods for heterogeneous teams of monitoring robots to improve their environment model through current interactions with the environment; concurrently collect data, process and assimilate it into the existing model, and plan on that model; accept high-level instruction and translate goal-oriented directives such as environmental monitoring into a suitable plan for sensing, reasoning, communicating, and acting through the underlying system architecture; and monitor their actions, optimize, and reconfigure autonomously. The heterogeneous team of robots proposed includes surface vehicles providing samples at the air-sea interface and aerial robots creating flow models and acting as intermediaries within the team. The hierarchical structure of the approach takes advantage of the natural boundaries defined by Lagrangian coherent structures in the creation of a distributed sensing framework.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research program was to extend the capabilities of heterogeneous robot teams in marine environments by overcoming the theoretical and technical challenges of developing a general mathematical and control framework for distributed autonomous sensing and monitoring of ocean processes for marine robotic operations. The research objectives of the proposal are: 1) Develop representations for geophysical flows for modeling large-scale marine environments, and use these representations to design efficient trajectories for robots moving in those flows; 2) Develop algorithms for coordinating heterogeneous teams of mobile sensing resources, including unmanned aerial and surface vehicles, to simultaneously monitor the flow field and process of interest, as well as process and use that data in real time; and 3) Experimentally validate the proposed strategies using a heterogeneous robot testbed, including aerial and marine vehicles in representative environments with simulated and actual flows.

 

This project has created fundamental knowledge about new ways that robots can better monitor, sense, and operate in dynamic and uncertain environments. Specifically, the project has developed distributed sensing, estimation, and tracking strategies for heterogeneous teams of mobile robots to track dynamic processes in flows.  Our techniques enable the team to build reduced-order-models (ROMs) of dynamic spatiotemporal processes by fusing multiscale data in a distributed, asynchronous fashion.  The ability to better model and predict the flows enables the development of energy efficient coordination and control strategies for multi-robot systems operating in dynamic fluid environments.  In particular, we have developed flow-based navigation, rendezvous, and docking strategies for teams of minimally actuated marine vehicles.   Through our work, we have successfully shown how the ability to learn, estimate, and model key dynamical environmental features can improve both a vehicle?s autonomy and its situational awareness and thus overall decision making capabilities. 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: M. Ani Hsieh

Images (1 of )
  • A heterogeneous robot team collecting different sensing information to create a cohesive model of a time varying environment. Vehicles collect low and high fidelity sensor measurements which are unified into one model for estimation and prediction of a time varying process.
    Salam and Hsieh, AURO 2023 (Under Review)
    Copyrighted
    M. Ani Hsieh
    Heterogeneous mobile sensing network
  • Trajectories of a Modboat (left) staying within a preset distance from the edge of the tank (red lines) at the ScalAR Lab flow tank (upper right). The vehicle only needs to exert occasional control since it leverages the flow (lower right).
    Knizhnik et al., ICRA 2022
    Copyrighted
    M. Ani Hsieh
    Modboat executing flow-based control

The goal of this research program was to extend the capabilities of heterogeneous robot teams in marine environments by overcoming the theoretical and technical challenges of developing a general mathematical and control framework for distributed autonomous sensing and monitoring of ocean processes for marine robotic operations. The research objectives of the proposal are: 1) Develop representations for geophysical flows for modeling large-scale marine environments, and use these representations to design efficient trajectories for robots moving in those flows; 2) Develop algorithms for coordinating heterogeneous teams of mobile sensing resources, including unmanned aerial and surface vehicles, to simultaneously monitor the flow field and process of interest, as well as process and use that data in real time; and 3) Experimentally validate the proposed strategies using a heterogeneous robot testbed, including aerial and marine vehicles in representative environments with simulated and actual flows.

 
This project has created fundamental knowledge about new ways that robots can better monitor, sense, and operate in dynamic and uncertain environments. Specifically, the project has developed distributed sensing, estimation, and tracking strategies for heterogeneous teams of mobile robots to track dynamic processes in flows.  Our techniques enable the team to build reduced-order-models (ROMs) of dynamic spatiotemporal processes by fusing multiscale data in a distributed, asynchronous fashion.  The ability to better model and predict the flows enables the development of energy efficient coordination and control strategies for multi-robot systems operating in dynamic fluid environments.  In particular, we have developed flow-based navigation, rendezvous, and docking strategies for teams of minimally actuated marine vehicles.   Through our work, we have successfully shown how the ability to learn, estimate, and model key dynamical environmental features can improve both a vehicle?s autonomy and its situational awareness and thus overall decision making capabilities.
